fields.description:
Hello, 
on the page https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWDKB/Essential+SQL+Queries+for+Crowd 

there is the query for getting all users that did not log in for a long time.
The Postgres example is wrong, as for Postgres there is no DATEDIFF function.
See: https://wiki.postgresql.org/wiki/Working_with_Dates_and_Times_in_PostgreSQL 

The selection of rows is not narrowed down enough, all attributes get casted to timestamps (which leads to errors if the attribute is a literal).
And the comparision at the end of the where clause cannot work, becuase the difference of two timestamps on Postgres is always an interval.
I amended the query so that it works with Postgres (tested agains postgres 9.3 with latest Crowd):

{code}
SELECT cwd_user.user_name, cwd_user.id, cwd_user.first_name, cwd_user.last_name, cwd_directory.id, cwd_directory.directory_name, to_timestamp(CAST(cwd_user_attribute.attribute_value as double precision)/1000)  
FROM cwd_user 
JOIN cwd_directory ON cwd_user.directory_id = cwd_directory.id 
JOIN cwd_user_attribute ON cwd_user.id = cwd_user_attribute.user_id 
WHERE 
cwd_user_attribute.attribute_name = 'lastAuthenticated'
AND CURRENT_TIMESTAMP - to_timestamp(CAST(cwd_user_attribute.attribute_value as double precision)/1000) > INTERVAL'90 days';
{code}
fields.summary: PostgreSQL query for Crowd wrong

fields.description:
AQL gives a common query language format from having a fixed common antlr 4 grammar, plus a set of plugin points for adding product-specific fields, functions and datatypes which we can use to extend the syntax in limited ways without modifying the grammar. It also allows adapting how those fields and functions map to a backend implementation without changing the grammar.

Adopting AQL would give Crowd a 'free' upgrade to antlr 4, and clear abstraction from that, making upgrading to antlr 5 easier.
fields.summary: Port CrowdQL to AQL

fields.description:
A MembershipQuery in Crowd today is limited to a very simplistic model of querying on the name of one end of a membership, and only supports exact matches on those names. To make more complex single DB round-trip queries possible, we should add support in the MembershipQuery to allow both ends of the membership to have SearchRestrictions, allowing pattern matching across usernames, group names, user attributes, and group attributes.

We should add this support to CrowdQL, Crowd REST Client, Crowd REST Plugin, CrowdService and the underlying DAO level QueryTranslator.
fields.summary: Support full SearchRestrictions on both entities in a MembershipQuery

fields.description:
Every time a token is validated, the value of {{cwd_token.last_accessed_time}} is updated. This field has a resolution of milliseconds which is very high for most use cases. By reducing the resolution we could reduce the number of times this field is updated and saved to the database.

This is important because any read-only request (like finding a user) via the REST API is authenticated, and Crowd refreshes the {{last_accessed_time}}, which is a write in the database. That means that read operations actually involve at least one write to the database, which is typically more expensive and less scalable.
fields.summary: Limit the frequency of updates to cwd_token.last_acccesed_time

fields.description:
To prevent too much work from happening at any one instance in time on the Crowd app for medium to large standalone Crowd installations, it may be useful to have synchronization intervals take place at intervals of prime numbers rather than every 60 minutes.  Crowd could keep track of how long each sync takes and move the ones that are quicker to lower sync interval periods (53, 59, 61) and move the ones that take longer to higher sync interval periods (97, 101, 103).  Having sync intervals triggered at prime number intervals would reduce the likelihood that multiple directories would have their sync processes running simultaneously (since primes aren't multiples of one another), and having directories that take longer to sync run at higher intervals would afford them more time to complete.

It's entirely possible that my idea is a solution looking for a problem, but I thought it would be better to enter the ticket than not.
fields.summary: Suggest prime number synchronization intervals

h5.Steps to Reproduce
# Install Crowd 2.8.3
# Create a connection to Active Directory
#* Enable Incremental Sync
#* Enable caching on the directory
#* Enable "Filter out Expired Users"
# Sync the directory (Crowd will perform a full sync first, this is expected)
# In Active Directory, cause a user account to expire
# Perform an incremental sync

h5.Expected Results
The logs should confirm the user is removed, and the user should not show up in the user screen

h5.Actual Results
The user is removed, but then re-added on the same sync. A second synchronization will remove the user correctly, and the user will not appear on the user screen.

Here's the behavior demonstrated in logs from Crowd:

2015-09-17 15:13:45,379 scheduler_Worker-8 INFO [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations] scanning [ 1 ] users to add or update
2015-09-17 15:13:45,379 scheduler_Worker-8 DEBUG [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations] user [ expired ] not found, adding
2015-09-17 15:13:45,381 scheduler_Worker-8 INFO [atlassian.crowd.directory.DirectoryCacheImplUsingChangeOperations] scanned and compared [ 1 ] users for update in DB cache in [ 6ms ]
2015-09-17 15:13:45,381 scheduler_Worker-8 INFO [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations] adding [ 1 ] users
2015-09-17 15:13:45,402 scheduler_Worker-8 INFO [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations] added [ 1 ] users successfully in [ 21ms ]

When an incremental sync fails, the logs are not very helpful in determining the cause. This makes it tough for support and DoS to diagnose these kinds of Crowd issues (which pop up way too much).

{noformat}
2015-09-14 17:16:31,320 INFO [scheduler_Worker-7] [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory] synchroniseCache INCREMENTAL synchronisation for directory [ 786433 ] starting
2015-09-14 17:16:31,321 INFO [scheduler_Worker-7] [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory] synchroniseCache Attempting INCREMENTAL synchronisation for directory [ 786433 ]
2015-09-14 17:16:31,358 INFO [scheduler_Worker-7] [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory] synchroniseCache Incremental synchronisation for directory [ 786433 ] was not completed, falling back to a full synchronisation
2015-09-14 17:16:31,358 INFO [scheduler_Worker-7] [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory] synchroniseCache INCREMENTAL synchronisation for directory [ 786433 ] was not successful, attempting FULL

h2. Solution

Something like this would be more ideal:

{noformat}
2015-09-14 17:16:31,320 INFO [scheduler_Worker-7] [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory] synchroniseCache INCREMENTAL synchronisation for directory [ 786433 ] starting
2015-09-14 17:16:31,321 INFO [scheduler_Worker-7] [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory] synchroniseCache Attempting INCREMENTAL synchronisation for directory [ 786433 ]
2015-09-14 17:16:31,352 ERROR [scheduler_Worker-7] [directory.ldap.cache.EventTokenChangedCacheRefresher] synchroniseChanges Incremental synchronisation failed: com.atlassian.crowd.event.user.UserRenamedEvent is not supported by incremental sync.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

In order to restrict synchronisations of certain users it currently needs to be done by configuring a LDAP search filter as per [How to write LDAP search filters|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DEV/How+to+write+LDAP+search+filters]. This can get particularly complicated when multiple groups, from different DNs are involved. Please provide some functionality within the UI to only synchronise users based on different groups, for different applications.

h3. Suggested Solution

This solution mentions JIRA, however is applicable for any application integrating with Crowd.

# Log into Crowd as administrator
# Go to Applications and click on your JIRA application.
# Click on "Groups"
Now you should see a list of all groups that can authenticate to JIRA (I'll use my instance for example).
Pearson AD - PEROOT users - jira-administrators	
Pearson AD - PEROOT users - jira-developers	
Pearson AD - PEROOT users - jira-users
Pearson Crowd - external users - jira-users-ext

Now, in JIRA, or in Crowd, there should be a checkbox option (it'll probably be easier to implement in JIRA, but if done in Crowd could be easily utilized by all Atlassian apps) to only sync authenticated groups.

What this would mean is that unless the user is a part of one of the above groupings, they are not synced into JIRA. This would cut down drastically on the number of users brought in, and alleviate the issues large instances such as our own have been experiencing. JIRA would no longer be forced to bring in user information for users that cannot access JIRA.

This would drop us from 80k users, back to our 8k, while still allowing us to authenticate through Crowd, manage our groups through Crowd, and leaves (as far as I can tell) all functionality intact.
fields.summary: As an admin I would like to synchronise users from certain groups only

# Once it is disabled, click Remove.

fields.description:
h1. Steps to reproduce

# Create a Remote Crowd directory (uncached in this case)
# Using the UI, set up a proxy host, proxy port, proxy username/password, HTTP connection timeout and max connections. For the purpose of this demonstration, set the proxy host/port to something that does not exist.
# Browse the contents of the directory

h1. Expected outcome

The connection should use the configured proxy and other HTTP connection parameters. Which means that the directory shouldn't work, because the proxy is misconfigured.

h1. Observed result

The directory works, which indicates that it is not attempting to use the proxy.
fields.summary: Remote Crowd directories ignore UI proxy settings and HTTP connection configuration

fields.description:
With two way mappings of data in Hibernate, you need to add extra code to ensure that both directions of the mappings are kept up to date. Failing to do so can lead to hibernate attempting to re-save a removed object in the mapping collection, or other bad side effects.

In this case, that means that whenever an attribute is added, updated or removed, its entry in the InternalUser.attributes set also needs to be added, updated or removed. The same goes for InternalGroup.attributes.
fields.summary: UserDao.removeAttribute does not keep InternalUser.attributes property up to date

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When Crowd is setup with SSL terminating at the proxy level, Crowd does not detect it is being accessed through HTTPS. Even if the different {{crowd.properties}} and {{build.properties}} files have an HTTPS URL, the logs and display URL (for application links) still displays the base URL as HTTP:
{noformat}
2015-08-22 20:03:20,637 localhost-startStop-1 INFO [service.soap.client.SoapClientPropertiesImpl] Loading property: 'application.name' : 'crowd'
2015-08-22 20:03:20,638 localhost-startStop-1 INFO [service.soap.client.SoapClientPropertiesImpl] Loading property: 'application.login.url' : 'http://domain.com/crowd'
2015-08-22 20:03:20,638 localhost-startStop-1 INFO [service.soap.client.SoapClientPropertiesImpl] Loading property: 'session.tokenkey' : 'session.tokenkey'
2015-08-22 20:03:20,638 localhost-startStop-1 INFO [service.soap.client.SoapClientPropertiesImpl] Loading property: 'session.lastvalidation' : 'session.lastvalidation'
2015-08-22 20:03:20,638 localhost-startStop-1 INFO [service.soap.client.SoapClientPropertiesImpl] Loading property: 'session.validationinterval' : '0'
2015-08-22 20:03:20,638 localhost-startStop-1 INFO [service.soap.client.SoapClientPropertiesImpl] Failed to find value for property: cookie.domain
2015-08-22 20:03:20,645 localhost-startStop-1 INFO [service.soap.client.SoapClientPropertiesImpl] Loading property: 'crowd.server.url' : 'http://domain.com/crowd/services/'
{noformat}

When configuring application links, we do see a useful prompt that addresses this:
{noformat}
The Application URL should only be different to the Display URL if your application cannot access the internet directly (e.g. behind a firewall or proxy).
{noformat}

!https://s3.amazonaws.com/uploads.hipchat.com/10804/2041359/UHzVzISkxhBIT1A/applicationlinkHTTPS.png!

h3. Suggested Solution
Crowd should detect that it is being accessed through HTTPS so as to make the display URL more accurate when rendered on the browser. This would also be useful in the logs so as to not confuse the base URL and configuration.
fields.summary: Enable Crowd to detect when HTTPS is set at the proxy level

fields.description: The match modes for a search via the CrowdService API allow for STARTS_WITH, CONTAINS, EXACT_MATCH, LESS_THAN, GREATER_THAN and NULL. We should add ENDS_WITH support, to bring it into feature parity with the old Atlassian User 3.0 API.
fields.summary: Support MatchMode.ENDS_WITH for CrowdService.search
404 error in 'Getting Support' page

fields.description: [RFC 2798|https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2798] allows a JPEG photo to be stored in LDAP ([{{jpegPhoto}}|https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2798#section-2.6]). Active Directory uses {{thumbnailPhoto}} for the same purpose. Retrieve and show them in the user profile page.
fields.summary: Retrieve avatars from LDAP for uncached directories

fields.description: {{ApplicationService#searchUsersAllowingDuplicateNames}} was deprecated due to lack of use back in 2.7; remove it.
fields.summary: Remove unused deprecated 'searchUsersAllowingDuplicateNames' method

fields.description: As a simpler version of CWD-2165, allow Crowd to use Gravatars for users.
fields.summary: Allow use of Gravatars

fields.description:
According to https://developer.atlassian.com/display/CROWDDEV/Crowd+REST+Resources#CrowdRESTResources-GroupResource, Crowd should return a 404 status code if any of the following two request are made:
{code}
/rest/usermanagement/1/user/group/direct?username=invalid
/rest/usermanagement/1/group/user/direct?groupname=invalid
{code}
given that {{invalid}} is not a valid group or user name

However, currently an empty list of groups/users is returned along with a 200 status.
fields.summary: Getting direct users/groups doesn't return 404 for invalid group/user

fields.description:
Users that does not have permission to login to applications appear in their people directories.

How to replicate the issue:

h3. In Crowd side:
1) Setup a crowd 2.8.x
2) Create "usera" and "userb" in Crowd internal directory
3) Create "groupa" and "groupb" in Crowd internal directory
4) Place the "usera" inside the "groupa" and "userb" inside "groupb" in Crowd 
5) Create a Confluence application in Crowd
6) Place the Crowd internal directory in the Confluence application
7) Allow just the "groupa" access to Confluence in Crowd UI

h3. In Confluence side:
8) Go to the administration -> user directories and create a Crowd user directory there
9) Configure the new directory to access the Confluence application setup in Crowd previously
10) Sync Confluence with the new Crowd user directory

h3. Actual behavior
* Confluence shows *all* users in the people directory ("usera" and "userb") even the ones that doesn't have access to the application in Crowd UI. Crowd transfer all users from the configured directories, no matter if they have access to the application or not.

h3. Expected Behavior:
* Confluence would sync just the allowed users in Crowd ("groupa" and "usera"). When going to the people directory in Confluence, just the "usera" should appear.
fields.summary: Users are synced with the application even if they don't have permissions to login

fields.description:
h1. Steps to reproduce

# Start a new instance of Crowd 2.8.3
# Add a Delegated LDAP directory (I use a local OpenLDAP), make sure “Synchronise user details” and “Synchronise group memberships” are checked
# Add the Delegated LDAP directory to the {{crowd}} application as the first directory.
# (Using an uncached Connector from Crowd or any LDAP tool) Create a user {{user}} and two groups {{group1}} and {{group2}} in LDAP. Add the user to both groups in LDAP.
# Using Crowd, create {{group2}} in the Delegated directory, but not {{group1}}.
# Log in to Crowd as user.

h1. Expected result

On login, the first group ({{group1}}) is copied to the Delegated directory in the database (is_local=false). The second group ({{group2}}) is not copied because it already exists locally (is_local=true) and therefore it is shadowed.

The membership of {{user}} to {{group1}} and {{group2}} is synchronised to the database.

h1. Observed behaviour

(/) On login, the first group ({{group1}}) is copied to the Delegated directory in the database (is_local=false). The second group ({{group2}}) is not copied because it already exists (is_local=true).

(x) The membership of user to group1 is copied, but the membership of user to group2 is not copied. While not overriding the definition of the local group is the expected behaviour, not synchronising the membership is a bug.

At the same time, in the console we see

{noformat}
WARN [atlassian.crowd.directory.DelegatedAuthenticationDirectory] Remote group "group2" in directory "Delegated authentication directory" is shadowed by a local group of the same name and will not be imported..
{noformat}

h1. Workarounds

* I've verified that manually changing the is_local field of the affected group from "true" to "false" and logging in again as the user brings the membership to Crowd. This change cannot be made using the UI, it must be made directly in the {{cwd_membership}} table of the database.
* If the group does not have any valuable information attached to it, then delete the local group using the UI and it will be re-created when the user logs in again.
* Uncheck the "Synchronise group memberships" option from the directory configuration and create the memberships manually after the user logs in.
fields.summary: Delegated LDAP does not synchronise on login the memberships of remote groups if they are shadowed by a local group

fields.description:
This issue is derived from two related JIRA and Confluence issues, JRA-12675 and CONF-13800 respectively.

The problem seems to stem from the way that lists of LDAP group names are serialised to strings. These group names may include commas, either straight 'mygroup, more' or escaped 'mygroup\, more', and code using the attribute {{DirectoryImpl.ATTRIBUTE_KEY_AUTO_ADD_GROUPS}} is converting pipe char '|' separators to comma ',' separators in code like EMBCWD's {{DefaultDirectoryMapper.pipeSeparatedGroupsToCommaSeparatedGroups}} method.

Ideally, lists of groups would be passed around as lists as much as possible and only serialised to a string at the point of storage in the DB, but refactoring this with API support throughout the affected products will be a substantial task.
fields.summary: Group names with commas are not supported as auto-add groups

fields.description:
When searching for users who do not have a custom attribute, Crowd generates a HQL query like

{code}
select distinct
  u.id as id1_17_,
  u.user_name as user_nam2_17_,
  u.lower_user_name as lower_us3_17_,
  u.active as active4_17_,
  u.created_date as created_5_17_,
  u.updated_date as updated_6_17_,
  u.first_name as first_na7_17_,
  u.lower_first_name as lower_fi8_17_,
  u.last_name as last_nam9_17_, u.lower_last_name as lower_l10_17_, u.display_name as display11_17_, u.lower_display_name as lower_d12_17_, u.email_address as email_a13_17_, u.lower_email_address as lower_e14_17_, u.external_id as externa15_17_, u.directory_id as directo16_17_, u.credential as credent17_17_
from cwd_user u
where
  (u.lower_user_name like '%a%' or u.lower_display_name like '%a%' or u.lower_email_address like '%a%')
  and u.active= 'T'
  and ('synch.servicedesk.requestor' not in  (select internalus1_.attribute_name from cwd_user_attribute internalus1_ where u.id=internalus1_.user_id))
order by u.lower_user_name;
{code}

The {{NOT IN}} in that query results in slower than necessary execution times.

Rewriting it to use {{NOT EXIST}} is approximately 30% faster according to timings given by postgresql's EXPLAIN ANALYZE, and more than twice as fast if there's a limit of 31 applied (some limit is the case in many real world queries).

{code}
select distinct
  u.id as id1_17_,
  u.user_name as user_nam2_17_,
  u.lower_user_name as lower_us3_17_,
  u.active as active4_17_,
  u.created_date as created_5_17_,
  u.updated_date as updated_6_17_,
  u.first_name as first_na7_17_,
  u.lower_first_name as lower_fi8_17_,
  u.last_name as last_nam9_17_, u.lower_last_name as lower_l10_17_, u.display_name as display11_17_, u.lower_display_name as lower_d12_17_, u.email_address as email_a13_17_, u.lower_email_address as lower_e14_17_, u.external_id as externa15_17_, u.directory_id as directo16_17_, u.credential as credent17_17_
from cwd_user u

where
  (u.lower_user_name like '%a%' or u.lower_display_name like '%a%' or u.lower_email_address like '%a%')
  and u.active= 'T'
  and not EXISTS (select 1 from cwd_user_attribute internalus1_ where u.id=internalus1_.user_id and internalus1_.attribute_name = 'synch.servicedesk.requestor' )
order by u.lower_user_name;
{code}
fields.summary: Search for users/groups without a custom attribute is inefficient due to use of NOT IN

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Microsoft SQL Server 2012 is officially supported in Crowd: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Supported+Platforms

Microsoft SQL Server 2012 *R2* is currently not part of the supported platforms for Crowd.

Microsoft SQL Server 2014 is currently not part of the supported platforms for Crowd.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add Microsoft SQL Server 2012 R2 and 2014 as supported databases for Crowd.
fields.summary: Official support for Microsoft SQL Server 2014

fields.description:
We are doing a proof of concept study on several Atlassian Products at the moment.

We have successfully installed the following: JIRA, Confluence, FishEye and Crowd. We have been able to synchronize users from CROWD to our Active Directory system and all users in Crowd are able to login on JIRA, CONFLUENCE and FISHEYE.

Our basic requirement for our environment is to have JIRA, CONFLUENCE and FISHEYE to have its own list users validated by Crowd (pulled from Active Directory). 

During the integration, we have encountered difficulties in setting up mutually exclusive list of users from JIRA, CONFLUENCE and FishEYE to validate the authentications using Crowd.

At this part it is not clear to us how we can achieve this? or if this is possible setup.
fields.summary: Setting up Crowd to Authenticate Users from JIRA, CONFLUENCE, FISHEYE

fields.description:
h3. Summary

As of Java 1.8u51+ (also 1.7.0_85+ and 1.6.0_101+) making SSL connections to an IP address is no longer allowed.  Previously the JVM would do a reverse lookup of the hostname using the IP then complete the connection using that hostname.  This was a security vulnerability because an attacker that gained control of DNS 
could route traffic to their own server.  This change is a security feature of Java.

We have found there is a problem with the way Java creates LDAPS connections.  The way Socket.createSocket() is used results in an SSLSocket without the hostname set in it.  This results in use of an IP address to make the connection and since this is no longer allowed the connection fails.  We have reported this problem to Oracle and also forwarded the information to the Java security dev list: http://mail.openjdk.java.net/pipermail/security-dev/2015-September/012845.html .

Because of this _*existing LDAPS connections are broken*_ and users from that user directory are unable to login including non-local administrators.

This will affect any customer using secure LDAP that upgrades the JVM.  Secure LDAP is very common to protect passwords on the internal network, particularly in enterprise environments.

h3. Environment
* Any version of Crowd using one of the noted Java versions.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Configure a user directory using a secure LDAP connection
# Upgrade the JDK to a noted Java version.


h3. Expected Results

Logins and LDAP syncs should work as normal.

h3. Actual Results

Users will be unable to authenticate and LDAP syncs will fail.

Errors like this will occur in the logs: {code:borderStyle=solid}
2015-07-22 12:43:05,896 WARN  [http-bio-443-exec-1] @1SDVDDx763x1x0 XXXXX "POST /j_stash_security_check HTTP/1.1" c.a.s.i.s.s.PluginAuthenticationProvider Could not authenticate XXXXX; authentication by com.atlassian.stash.stash-authentication:crowdHttpAuthHandler failed
com.atlassian.stash.user.AuthenticationSystemException: The remote authentication server is not available. Please try again later.
	at com.atlassian.stash.internal.crowd.RiotPolice.authenticate(RiotPolice.java:113) ~[stash-service-impl-3.11.1.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.stash.internal.user.DefaultUserService.authenticate(DefaultUserService.java:108) ~[stash-service-impl-3.11.1.jar:na]
...
	... 21 common frames omitted
Caused by: org.springframework.transaction.CannotCreateTransactionException: Could not create DirContext instance for transaction; nested exception is org.springframework.ldap.CommunicationException: <DNS.NAME>:636; nested exception is javax.naming.CommunicationException: <DNS.NAME>:636 [Root exception is javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: java.security.cert.CertificateException: No subject alternative names matching IP address XXXXX found]
	at org.springframework.transaction.compensating.support.AbstractCompensatingTransactionManagerDelegate.doBegin(AbstractCompensatingTransactionManagerDelegate.java:90) ~[spring-ldap-core-2.0.2.RELEASE.jar:2.0.2.RELEASE]
...
	... 22 common frames omitted
Caused by: org.springframework.ldap.CommunicationException: <DNS.NAME>:636; nested exception is javax.naming.CommunicationException: <DNS.NAME>:636 [Root exception is javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: java.security.cert.CertificateException: No subject alternative names matching IP address XXXXX found]
	at org.springframework.ldap.support.LdapUtils.convertLdapException(LdapUtils.java:108)
...
	... 39 common frames omitted
Caused by: javax.naming.CommunicationException: <DNS.NAME>:636
	at com.sun.jndi.ldap.Connection.<init>(Unknown Source) ~[na:1.8.0_51]
	at com.sun.jndi.ldap.LdapClient.<init>(Unknown Source) ~[na:1.8.0_51]
...
	... 43 common frames omitted
Caused by: javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: java.security.cert.CertificateException: No subject alternative names matching IP address XXXXX found
	at sun.security.ssl.Alerts.getSSLException(Unknown Source) ~[na:1.8.0_51]
	at sun.security.ssl.SSLSocketImpl.fatal(Unknown Source) ~[na:1.8.0_51]
...
	... 58 common frames omitted
Caused by: java.security.cert.CertificateException: No subject alternative names matching IP address XXXXX found
	at sun.security.util.HostnameChecker.matchIP(Unknown Source) ~[na:1.8.0_51]
...
	... 67 common frames omitted
{code}

h2. Fix: install a Java version equal to or newer than 1.8u65

Java version 1.8u65 contains a fix [JDK-8133196|https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8133196] which addresses the problem described in this issue.  Please see [How to Use System JRE Instead of Embedded JRE|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/How+to+Use+System+JRE+Instead+of+Embedded+JRE] for instructions to change the version of Java that JIRA runs with.

h3. Workaround

(!) Only necessary if you do not upgrade your Java JDK.

h5. Add JVM startup parameter {{-Djdk.tls.trustNameService=true}}

This reverts back to the older Java behavior while preserving all the other security related changes in the newer Java release.  Your LDAP data will still be encrypted.  The risk is described by Oracle in their explanation of the change at http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/8u51-relnotes-2587590.html.

h5. Disable SSL check

 Under the LDAP connection "Advanced Settings" set "Secure SSL" to disabled*.  As stated in the UI this will disable all verification of the SSL certificate.  Your LDAP data will still be encrypted.  (!) This workaround may represent a greater vulnerability as any SSL cert could be substituted with no need to compromise a DNS server.
fields.summary: Secure LDAP connections are broken when using Java 1.8u51, 1.8u60, 1.7.0_85+ and 1.6.0_101+

fields.description:
From the page http://jdbc.postgresql.org/download.html:
{quote}
If you are using the 1.6 then you should use the JDBC4 version. If you are using 1.7 or 1.8 then you should use the JDBC41 version.
{quote}
Since Crowd 2.8,  Java 7 and Java 8 is supported, but we still ship with PostgreSQL 9.0 JDBC4 

h3.Workaround
Download the JDBC41 driver from http://jdbc.postgresql.org/download.html and replace the existing PostgreSQL driver in _$Crowd_Install/apache-tomcat/lib_
fields.summary: Crowd is shipped with Postgres JDBC4 instead of JDBC41

fields.description:
AD directory has read-only LDAP user set i.e. can't write anything back to AD in the first place.

A use becomes inactive in AD and after sync becomes "Active = False" in Crowd. (Why? Isn't it set to manage locally?)

The same user then becomes active in AD again, but sync doesn't pick it up.

It's impossible to change the status via GUI (due to CWD-4311)

If one updates the database directly (set active=T) and re-runs sync - the user stays active.

Disabling "Manage User Status Locally" makes sync pick up and correctly activate several other users in Crowd without the need for db update.


Guessing this is done during sync


configured to have "Manage User Status Locally" = Yes
fields.summary: AD sync is inconsistent with "Manage User Status Locally"

fields.description:
My organization utilizes a configuration management system for the deployment of all new services. This ensures that every server of ours is deployed in a repeatable, consistent, and automated fashion. We've been able to automate everything up to first launch of the crowd service. However, at that point a human must log into the provisioned crowd system to enter the license key and manually complete setup.

We would like to request that a supported method for unattended installation of a fresh crowd server implemented, along with a supported method for unattended restoration of a backup. Ideally this would take the form of file in the crowd home directory specifying the various options that would usually be entered during an attended installation. When the crowd service starts, it could check for the existence of this file and the absence of the other crowd configuration files. If this condition exists, the crowd server could then proceed through the initialization of the server without human input utilizing the configuration parameters provided in the file.
fields.summary: Provide a supported method for unattended installations

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

When Crowd reach the maximum database connection, there will be nothing logged in Crowd logs until deadlock recorded. It would be great if Crowd could logged this which administrator can catch to create a notification out of it.

h3. Suggested Resolution

Allow Crowd to logged this event in application log.

h3. Workaround

Use third party monitor tools to catch the amount of database connection used by Crowd.

fields.description:
It would be great if we could set "Allow all to authenticate" *but* a few groups, instead of not _allowing all to authenticate_ and specifying each group that should be able to log in.

Let's say I've got 100 groups on my internal Crowd directory and only one of these groups I do not want to allow the _login_ to my _Confluence_ application. In this case I'd need to add all 99 groups as allowed to login, whereas it would be much easier to specify the only group not allowed to log in.
fields.summary: Option to exclude specific groups from logging into an application

fields.description:
See https://jdog.jira-dev.com/browse/SDR-389 for details.

In short, UPM is not responding to Service Desk agent changes in JIRA 7.0, and as a result it's possible to add more agents than the user is licensed for without Service Desk becoming disabled. We've narrowed down the problem to Crowd not firing the expected events when agents are updated.

This is a blocker for JIRA's 7.0 release.
fields.summary: Crowd is not firing DirectoryEvent when Service Desk agents are modified in JIRA 7.0

fields.description: Planning on upgrading to Active Directory 2012 R2 and need to know if integrates with the current crowd we are running (2.5.6) and we will be upgrading to 2.8 very shortly
fields.summary: Crowd 2.8 integrated with Active Directory 2012 R2

fields.description:
Bundled Tomcat misses a default value for the {{CATALINA_PID}} variable, hence Tomcat doesn't create a pid file which makes it hard for systemd startup scripts to recognize if the Tomcat instance has started up (and respectivele systemd can't tell if Tomcat is still running or was shut down correctly).

Attached is an example code snipped that can be added to {{apache-tomcat/bin/setenv.sh}} to make it work:

{code}
# set the location of the pid file
if [ -z "$CATALINA_PID" ] ; then
    if [ -n "$CATALINA_BASE" ] ; then
        CATALINA_PID="$CATALINA_BASE"/work/catalina.pid
    elif [ -n "$CATALINA_HOME" ] ; then
        CATALINA_PID="$CATALINA_HOME"/work/catalina.pid
    fi
fi
export CATALINA_PID
{code}
fields.summary: Crowd's Tomcat setenv.sh misses CATALINA_PID variable

fields.description:
It would be helpful to be able to keep logical names for a group that are implemented through a common implementation group. 

Or be able to retire / merge a group without concerning users.
fields.summary: Allow admin to alias a group as another group name

fields.description:
Integrating Crowd and Apache through SSL include configuring some directives that are not documented very well, for example CrowdCertPath and CrowdSSLVerifyPeer.

Since Crowd administrators doesn't have the guide necessary to help them on this, they need to make some guess and assumption to successfully configure Apache Crowd integration which will waste their time and effort.
fields.summary: Provide Documentation for CrowdCert and CrowdSSLVerifyPeer Directives

fields.description: Struts intends to remove support for the optional `do` prefix for method names ([WW-4439|https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/WW-4439]). As this is still used in places (to get an idea of the methods, in actions, returning {{String}} and starting with '{{do}}': {{git grep 'public String do' | grep 'src/main.*/action/'}}), it should be removed to allow an upgrade.
fields.summary: Remove use of the 'do' prefixes in action method names

fields.description:
Due to global AD naming policies, we cannot just use "crowd-administrators" as the name of our group that our crowd admins go into - they in the formation Region-Company-City-Address-crowd-administrars - after the upgrade, I was unable to login with my AD synced account (local admin details are under lock and key as they provide no audit trail as to who does what etc) and was only logged in as a non-privileged user.

I requested the local admin details and logged in and under Applications > Crowd > Groups - there was only crowd-administrators (YRGroup Crowd) and our AD backed group was no longer there.

Re-adding it was simple enough and fixed the problem, however think this is something that should be investigated/resolved ASAP
fields.summary: Upgrade reset groups to just crowd-administrators

fields.description:
I just upgraded to 2.8.3 and our global policy is that high level admin users accounts (that we use as admins accounts on our atlassian apps) are not allowed to be mail enabled. Crowd pulls from AD and it's read only sync.

When I logged in for the first time, I was taken to a My Profile page - the email address was empty as it should have been, I hit update and got "The supplied email address is invalid.". Trying to give it an email address gives an "You do not have permission to update your profile."

Given it's a read only directory, there shouldn't even be an update button.
fields.summary: Profile update for r/o directory

fields.description:
When configuration the users allowed to access an application in Crowd, there is a little conflict problem.

Context : 
* Two or more directories are declared in Crowd
* Two of the directories contain a group with the same name

Example :
* Directory A
** group FOO
** group BAR
* Directory B
** group FOO
** group TER

We can see that directories A and B contain the same group name FOO.

Depending on the order of directories in the Directories tab of the application configuration, only one group FOO is visible. If Directory A is first, then available group in Groups configuration will be FOO (Directory A). If Directory B is first, only FOO (Directory B) will be visible.

If we want to allow both FOO groups to access the application, Crowd does not allow us to do it.

Could you please allow Crowd to make all groups from allowed directories in Groups configuration, wether they have the same name or not, please ?

Workaround :
If Directory A is first :
* Add Group FOO from Directory A to allowed groups
* Change directories order to put Directory B first in the directories order
* Add Group FOO from Directory B to allowed groups
* Change back directories order

Groups FOO from both directories will be allowed to access the application, and directory order is respected.
fields.summary: Group not visible for application configuration when two directories contain the same groupe name

fields.description:
After revoking access on a Crowd application, Crowd keeps alive the user session of those users that have already logged in, thus the user that should not have access any longer will still be able to access the application while their session exists.

*Steps to reproduce:*
# Set up a Crowd
# Create a local user called {{localcrowd}}, for example
# Go to _Applications_ tab and select the _Crowd_ one
# Under _Authentication test_ tab, try to authenticate with the _localcrowd_ user and it should fail
# Now click on the _Directories_ tab inside the Crowd application
# Select _True_ on _Allow all to authenticate_ for the _Atlassian Crowd server_ directory and click on _Update_
# Now go on the _Authentication test_ tab once again and try to login with the _localcrowd_ user. You should be able to authenticate now
# Go back to the _Directories_ tab inside the Crowd application and set _False_ for _Allow all to authenticate_ now and click on _Update_
# Once again try to authenticate the _localcrowd_ user
#* Expected behaviour: _localcrowd_ user should fail the authentication test
#* Actual behaviour: _localcrowd_ user is able to authenticate

This can represent a *security concern in terms of user access to applications*. If you want to remove a specific user access to some application, it probably means the user should not access this application content anymore and it should happen instantaneously for crowd and subsequently to any application syncing with Crowd (depending on the sync interval).

*Workaround:*
Go under _Current sessions_ under your Crowd admin panel and select the _User sessions_ tab. There you'll be able to see all existing sessions for users. Find the users that should not be able to login on the changed application any longer and click on _Expire_. This will force Crowd to validate the user permission to login when they try to log into the application again.
fields.summary: Users Sessions are not flushed automatically after removal of Application Permissions
